channel.title: health on Newsround
channel.description: Recent content in health on Newsround

item.title: Scientists conduct a comprehensive review showing the health benefits of cold water therapy - Earth.com
item.description: Cold water therapy reduces stress and may improve sleep, but effects fade quickly. Some people report feeling healthier over extended periods.

item.title: Study Confirms Why Some People Get Drunk Without Touching Alcohol - ScienceAlert
item.description: Scientists have confirmed in the largest study of its kind that bacteria, not fungi, are the major culprit in auto-brewery syndrome, a rare medical condition where people become intoxicated after eating, despite not consuming any alcohol.

item.title: America's New Favorite Snack Might Actually Be Putting Your Health At Risk - BuzzFeed
item.description: Food journalist Elizabeth Dunn tells us why you should consider steering clear of this beloved food.

item.title: RFK-backed infant vaccine study in Africa to proceed despite backlash, U.S. says - The Washington Post
item.description: U.S. funding for a study on the timing of hepatitis B vaccine doses in infants in Guinea-Bissau has sparked confusion and ethics concerns.

item.title: New research shows eating less ultraprocessed food supports healthier aging - PBS
item.description: A new study found older adults whose diets consisted of only 15% ultraprocessed foods – rather than the usual 50% – had lower weight, insulin and cholesterol.

item.title: This Is the Heart-Healthy Lunch a Cardiologist Actually Eats—and It’s Delicious - EatingWell
item.description: Boost your heart health and energy with a simple, delicious lunch idea recommended by cardiologists.

item.title: Tylenol in pregnancy is safe, says research prompted by Trump autism claims - KSL News
item.description: Taking Tylenol during pregnancy is safe, a group of European ​researchers have said, after compiling data in response to U.S. President Donald Trump’s claims of a link to autism last year.

item.title: Scientists Preparing to Simulate Human Brain on Supercomputer - Futurism
item.description: Researchers at the Jülich Research Centre in Germany are working on a simulation at the scale of the entire human brain.

item.title: New $11.25M park near San Antonio will be a first-of-its-kind - MySA
item.description: A planned Kendall County park in the Texas Hill Country will include a waterway for floating, kayaking and canoeing on the Guadalupe River.

item.title: Fiber is coming for coffee’s protein craze - Salon.com
item.description: Coffee experts say fiber could eclipse protein as the next functional add-in to your morning cup

item.title: Here’s What Happens When You Eat Greek Yogurt Every Day, According to Registered Dietitians - Real Simple
item.description: Discover what happens to your body when you eat Greek yogurt everyday, according to registered dietitians.

item.title: People’s Pharmacy: Doesn’t testosterone replacement therapy contribute to risk of heart attacks and cancer? - OregonLive.com
item.description: New studies are showing a reversal in this common conception.

item.title: WA sees measles outbreak for first time in years - The Seattle Times
item.description: Snohomish County’s health officer said he “firmly believes” there are other measles infections in the state that public health teams have not yet found.

item.title: Wait… All Those Studies May Have Detected Microplastics in the Human Body Because of a Severe Error - Futurism
item.description: Some scientists are coming out against the studies that claimed to have found alarming amounts of microplastics in human bodies.

item.title: A head-on car crash sidelined a young mom. A rare transplant was the only option to get her life back. - CBS News
item.description: Lacy Cornelius Boyd needed IV nutrition and an ileostomy bag after a devastating car crash. A rare transplant was her only option.

item.title: Scientists Discovered a Sugar That Doesn’t Spike Insulin, and They Say It’s Ready for the Market - Indian Defence Review
item.description: A naturally occurring sugar that’s nearly as sweet as table sugar, significantly lower in calories, and doesn’t trigger insulin spikes could soon become widely available.

item.title: The near death — and last-minute reprieve — of a trial for an HIV vaccine - NPR
item.description: A trial was about to launch for a vaccine that would ward off the HIV virus. It would be an incredible breakthrough. Then it looked as if it would be over before it started.

item.title: Experts Warn These Early Dementia Signs Often Get Missed — But Early Detection Makes A Big Difference - HuffPost
item.description: Dementia is common, but there are things you can do to reduce your risk or slow the progression of the disease.

item.title: Scientists Put Flu Patients in a Room With Healthy People—No One Got Sick. Why? - Women's Health
item.description: New research suggests effective flu-prevention strategies after trying to infect people with the virus. Here’s what the study found, and expert advice.

item.title: New U.S. guidance says to consume less alcohol. What does that mean? - Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
item.description: The new dietary guidelines are the first since 1980 to not define what drinking in moderation looks like.

item.title: Woman Says ‘Nothing Could Have Prepared’ Her for the ‘Level of Suffering’ She Would Endure After Shocking Diagnosis (Exclusive) - Yahoo News UK
item.description: The 28-year-old tells PEOPLE she spends “95%” of the day lying down, as standing for just a few minutes leads to “unbearable” pain

item.title: A scientist questioned new microplastics findings. Then other researchers fired back. - The Washington Post
item.description: A prominent scientist criticized microplastics research methods. Others are defending the work.

item.title: An endocrinologist tried a new weight loss approach and it worked - ScienceDaily
item.description: A simple change in how primary care clinics approach weight management is delivering big public health wins. PATHWEIGH lets patients openly request help and gives doctors the tools to focus entire visits on weight care. In a massive real-world trial, the prog…

item.title: Where saving lives gets personal: Small town hospital fights back against a medical menace - Pittsburgh Post-Gazette
item.description: ‘This is my community.’

item.title: Forget 'new year, new me' — these 5 'old school' muscle-building moves sculpt you in all the right places - Tom's Guide
item.description: Want to build strength and muscle in the gym? Let’s go old school

item.title: A fifth child dies of flu in Massachusetts, adult deaths up to 107 this season, according to state health officials - The Boston Globe
item.description: National health officials say 32 children have died from from flu so far this year and estimate there have been 9,300 US adult deaths.

item.title: New measles case confirmed in Polk County, total in NC rises to 8 since December - WLOS
item.description: The North Carolina Department of Health and Human Services, along with the Polk County Public Health Division, has confirmed a new case of measles in Polk Count

item.title: Measles case found in Clackamas County; 3rd reported by Oregon health officials this week - KATU
item.description: A measles case was reported in Clackamas County, the Oregon Health Authority said Friday, marking the third reported case in the state within the past week.Stat

item.title: Therapists Are Sharing What People With Big Penises Bring Up Most During Their Therapy Sessions - BuzzFeed
item.description: When it comes to penis size, bigger doesn’t always mean better.

item.title: Toddler dies from flu in Virginia - The Washington Post
item.description: Virginia reported the state’s first pediatric death this flu season.

item.title: COVID pandemic enters seventh year with no end in sight - Boing Boing
item.description: It’s strange to think that the COVID-19 pandemic, which sent the world into lockdown seven years ago never ended. It continues to kill and cripple us, to this day. We…

item.title: Driver Locks Eyes With Rare Animal In Tree — A 1-In-750,000 Sight - The Dodo
item.description: “The entire encounter was awesome …"

item.title: DOH reports travel-related Zika, dengue cases on Oahu - Honolulu Star-Advertiser
item.description: The Hawaii Department of Health said a travel-related Zika virus case has been confirmed on Oahu.

item.title: The Best Medicine For Joint Pain Isn't What You Think, Says Expert - ScienceAlert
item.description: Stiff knees, aching hips, and the slow grind of chronic joint pain are often accepted as an unavoidable part of getting older.

item.title: Deadly bacterial outbreak discovered at Berkeley homeless encampment - KTVU
2-year-old with ‘beautiful smile’ identified as first child flu death this season in N.J. - NJ.com
item.description: The child was not vaccinated for the flu, his family said.

item.title: Trini couple return home to focus on stigma of obesity - Trinidad and Tobago Newsday
item.description: A PAIR of Trini-born US board-certified doctors has returned to the twin islands to set up a practice which focuses on obesity and metabolic health.

item.title: 'Strange Trail' In Snow Leads Couple To A Tiny Animal Struggling To Survive - The Dodo
item.description: They found him just in time.

item.title: Neuroscientists Decipher Procrastination: A Brain Mechanism Explains Why People Leave Certain Tasks for Later - WIRED
item.description: New research has discovered that a neural circuit may explain procrastination. Scientists were able to disrupt this connection using a drug.

item.title: The 9 Best High-Protein Yogurts, According to a Dietitian - TODAY.com
item.description: Yogurt is a flavorful food celebrated for its protein content, but some have more of it than others. A registered dietitian ranks the best high-protein yogurts.

item.title: Veteran Firefighter Denied Insurance Coverage for Stage 4 Lung Cancer Treatment: ‘I Am Forced to Stand Here and Beg’ - Yahoo News UK
item.description: “An insurance company decided that profits matter more than the life of a man who spent his career protecting this city,” said Ken Jones’ daughter

item.title: Patches of low vaccination in the US are becoming bigger, riskier holes - CNN
item.description: Opting out of childhood vaccines is becoming more common across most of the United States, leaving larger shares of the population vulnerable to preventable diseases like measles, which is continuing its record-breaking spread across the country.

item.title: Disease tolerance and infection pathogenesis age-related tradeoffs in mice - Nature
item.description: Disease course and pathology an infection may cause can change owing to the structural and functional physiological changes that accumulate with age, but therapy can be tailored accordingly; disease tolerance genes show antagonistic pleiotropy.

item.title: A foundation model for continuous glucose monitoring data - Nature
item.description: GluFormer, a generative foundation model, uses continuous glucose monitoring data to accurately forecast glycaemia-related health responses, particularly for long-term outcomes.

item.title: What's behind this country's dramatic drop in the number of new orphans? - NPR
item.description: A new study offers good news from Uganda — although the cuts in U.S. aid cast a shadow over the reduction in deaths of parents from HIV/AIDS.

item.title: Scientists finally uncover why statins cause muscle pain - ScienceDaily
item.description: A new discovery may explain why so many people abandon cholesterol-lowering statins because of muscle pain and weakness. Researchers found that certain statins can latch onto a key muscle protein and trigger a tiny but harmful calcium leak inside muscle cells…

item.title: 18 Myths About Your Health You Can Ignore in 2026 - CNET
item.description: When science disagrees with conventional wisdom.

item.title: Cancer might evade immune defences by stealing mitochondria - Nature
item.description: Hijacking the energy-producing organelles from immune cells seems to help tumours in mice to infiltrate lymph nodes.

item.title: Massive brain study reveals why memory loss can suddenly speed up with age - ScienceDaily
item.description: A massive international brain study has revealed that memory decline with age isn’t driven by a single brain region or gene, but by widespread structural changes across the brain that build up over time. Analyzing thousands of MRI scans and memory tests from …
